title: Good Enough Language Comprehension: Effects of Reanalysis Difficulty on Comprehension and Production of Subsequent Mater
abstractText:
The goal of this work is to evaluate how the language comprehension system negotiates the trade-off between interpreting material already received and working on the current language task.

One set of studies will focus on the hypothesis that comprehension of material following a point of difficulty will be shallow and superficial to the extent that the system devotes significant resources to trying to process that difficult material.

The other set of studies tests the hypothesis that if the comprehension system devotes processing effort to understanding the input it has received, it will be harder for the production system to generate a follow-up utterance.

This research will connect the field of psycholinguistics to neighbouring disciplines such as decision-making, where it is known that people use simple heuristics to make complex decisions, and that people make use of a 'stopping rule' which establishes a criterion for when the decision-making system should stop deliberating. A related aim is to explore questions in psycholinguistics that are relevant to dialogue and communication. An important feature of real-world dialogue is that listeners do not have control over how material is presented to them, and they must coordinate the demands of listening and speaking.
